author: revelar
title: Revelar Game Engine - Operations
description: Revelar builds and has actively participated since Fund 6, building the Cardano Ecosystem for Gamers & Developers without outside capital.

f6_assessments.q0:
Revelar platform is an application made to easier the process for game developers of building on Cardano. Apart from gaming tools, the team is involved in educating players and developers through guides/podcasts. 
This proposal from Revelar team is made to enable the general operation of the Revelar platform and fund the expansion its services during second semester of 2022. The problem stated by the proposal is that the platform has been build so far without outside capital. By enabling team members to work full time on the project, outside capital could bring faster development to the platform, with less constraints if this capital comes from Catalyst than from other usual shareholders. The objective is to attract new game developers to Cardano, and the success is defined by a net growth in cardano-based game powered by Revelar of 25 over the 12 coming months. 
This proposal is aligned with the Dapps and integrations challenge: this challenge is open to competents teams that have already deployed a MVP. Here the MVP is the revelar platform and the Duo NFT Card Game based on Cardano. An NFT Game engine has the potential to have a large impact on the NFT activity on Cardano, has it is a catalyst for game developers. However, as stated by the proposal requests for general operation funding is unusual, and not completely aligned with the challenge that focusses more on engineering and development.
While I strongly agree that Revelar can have a large impact on Cardano, I’m not convinced that it is the right use of Catalyst funds to fund normal operation. That’s why I chose a score of 4 for Impact and Challenge allignement.
f6_assessments.q1:
The revelar core team is identified and existing developments show that they are relyable in delivering what is promised. Even if this proposal requests to fund general operations for a Dapp, the team has made a good effort to provide a detailed budget breakdown and to detail intermediate deliverables. 
A short risk analysis is given, but I’m lacking details to assess the feasibility with respect to the goal of 25 NET cardano-based game. A partnership with a dev shop is mentioned, but without a detailed roadmap for the platform development it is not easy to understand how critical these external ressources will be. For future application I recommend the team to connect the risk analysis with the goal that is defined, that should help feasibility assessment.
I agree that this proposal is highly likely to be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
The team offers a dedicated space for progress reports about Catalyst funded proposal: https://catalyst.revelar.co. Every voters can check by himself the progress of the 5 funded proposals in Fund 7. A github repos is updated for open source code and projects.
For this general operation budget proposal, the team offers to publish on github an open accounting ledger from their bookkeeper, and monthly video updates.
Based on how transparent this team is since Fund 7 and on the proposed information means for this proposal, I strongly agree that the community will have the possibility to monitor the progress of this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: The idea described considers all the chain analytics needed for game developers on Cardano. The Revelar team have worked on previous proposals and have been successful in managing the developers' games on-chain, with a healthy mix of open source resources, business operation transparency, and community engagement. That seems like a useful, indeed, integration that would add some value to the whole CNFT (Cardano NFT) ecosystem and consequently the whole ecosystem of Cardano. The KPIs considering bringing new games on Cardano and this is among the challenge settings. From all view, I believe that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge and I consider it as a great idea to follow-up.
f6_assessments.q1: I like the fact that the proposer gives many details about the skills and experience of all the involved team members, which skills are very impressive and relevant for that specific proposal. The links provided are also very useful and I see that there are also the twitter links and a couple of discord channels, something we do not meet on every proposal. The plan that has been provided is detailed and in my opinion, implementable as from the description for each phase I can see that there has been a lot of thought on how this idea is going to roll up. The budget has been outlined and has been broken down into identifiable items. Nevertheless, I believe it would be really informative if more details about the budget categories were available, for the voters not to wonder why the budget will be broken down in this manner. Another area where more information would be welcomed is the programming languages and technologies that will be needed for the project to be successful.
f6_assessments.q2: I find it useful that the proposer provided a roadmap and that they define success for this experiment in budget request falls in a few incremental milestones. The KPIs are briefly there (they are not that obvious to someone who does not know any of your previous work) but they some numbers for those metrics may be applied there, in order to quantify the success apart from describing it. Something else that I personally find really useful, is that domain you provided there which consists of all your previous work on Catalyst, so that anyone is able to visit and audit the success of the proposal. It is something that we do not see that often on Catalyst proposals. Among these lines, I believe that the proposal could be a success if only the proposer gives a little bit more information to the points I mentioned above.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is a proposal by Revelar, a company which has been working on Cardano projects using Catalyst funding since Fund6. In this instance, they are attempting a new approach with their company, where they would like to receive funds to cover their operational costs for the next 6 months, so that they can focus on research and development, brainstorming new ideas, expanding their team and generally growing their business to be able to deliver more and more software in Catalyst. It’s an interesting idea and I personally think it’s worth a shot, since I’ve interacted personally with Jason and a few of his colleagues and they seem to be transparent, talented, good people. I see it as a Catalyst Swarm, but where the Swarm is focused on communication and hosting events to spread knowledge and build up the community, this would be focused on advancing Cardano tech by allowing developers the freedom to experiment. It might prove to have a very big impact on Cardano, because, interesting fact, this is something the very successful company behind Steam and games like Half life or Dota 2 does: they have a culture where people are allowed to spend time on coming up with ideas, gathering people around them and then petition management for funding, if they get enough support. 
As risks, the proposers identify 3 items: 
- the fact that if they grow too fast they might not be able to deliver all their products and other Catalyst proposals at the expected quality level and some things may break (but they mitigate by testing as ahead of time as possible and they would use the resources here to cover this risk even further)
- subjective budgeting, which, from what I understand is referring to the fact that with these funds being fully visible to everyone, some people might raise objections to how they are used, but this will be simple to mitigate, as if the community and IOG notice that Revelar fails to deliver, they will simply cut off the funding, which is done on a monthly basis
- software delays, which are always a risk, in any software project, but as way to mitigate this, Revelar plans to re-use a lot of existing tech (theirs and open source) and they are also partnered with a company called Excellarate, which they can obtain developers from if some projects are more demanding.
All in all, this is a different approach to proposals, it’s slightly experimental, but as I described above, I think it’s worth taking a risk and seeing how it works. Score: 5.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers provide a timeline for the next 6 months and they describe their milestones and deliverables in a lot of detail, stating what they aim to achieve by the end of each month (for example, open up their finances and make them completely transparent by June).
The budget breakdown is also very well detailed, outlining hourly costs for the next 6 months with various internal tasks and processes: accounting & compliance, tools & subscriptions, infrastructure, hr, etc.
As to what concerns the team, we are provided with proper descriptions and social links for the company’s CEO, CTO and CCO, which can be used to follow their activity or get in touch with them by anyone in the community. 
I think that it’s very likely Revelar will continue delivering good software in the ecosystem if this proposal is funded. Score: 5.
f6_assessments.q2:
For Auditability, we are provided with Revelar’s website (https://catalyst.revelar.co), where they regularly post updates on all their Catalyst proposals. As they deliver open source software, the appropriate repositories will also be synced with this Gitbook. The CEO, Jason, also pledges to do monthly video updates on the company’s activity (similar to what IOG is doing!). They are also inviting members of the Catalyst Challenge teams to follow their activity and act as a “Board of Directors”, which can hold them accountable for how funds are spent.
This proposal will be considered a success if Revelar manages to become fully transparent with their accounting, thus paving the way for other companies as well to attempt to access funding in this way and if they continue to grow the amount of projects they deliver, as well as their own team.
With all the information we have been given, as well as the company’s openness to collaborating with the Catalyst community, I think this proposal will be auditable. Score: 5.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal does not fit the challenge as a) it does not seek funding for dApp or integration development and b) it doesn’t follow the recommendation: “This challenge is suitable for incorporated technology or blockchain companies and larger projects with competent teams that already have deployed MVPs. Ideally, these are projects that have a proven user base. Projects that satisfy such criteria are welcome to apply for more than $100,000 if that can be justified and clearly budgeted for.”
f6_assessments.q1: Revelar wants “to see if there is enough value/vision at this point in time to be fully community funded for 2022 with our general operations budget”. As a member of that community, I would say no. Since Revelar has been set up as a profit-seeking company, it should be able to stand on its own and either generate revenue to cover the costs or attract investors to foot the bill. Customers pay for the value they receive and investors get shares of the company. Here nothing is offered in exchange. “If there is positive feedback and reception, we may continue this model for future Operational budget requests.“ Revelar is not a charity and it should not subsist on community donations. This proposal is actually a bit worrying: what happens if they don’t get funding for their operations? Do they have reserves to pay for these things themselves? Will they have investor backing if needed? Or will everything come tumbling down if they cannot cover the costs of basic operation via Catalyst funding?
f6_assessments.q2: Revelar is exemplary in their ways of providing open and transparent tracking and follow-up through textual and video materials, both reporting to the Catalyst Coordinator and via their Gitbook (https://catalyst.revelar.co). Here, however, there are no results to be tracked, only spending. The costs are clearly divided between Developer Community Growth & Education, Accounting & Compliance, Productivity Tools & Subscriptions, Utilities, Cloud Infrastructure, Documentation, Marketing & PR, Support and QA User Testing. I don’t support the approach but I cannot deny the proposal’s clarity and auditability.

f6_assessments.q0: This is an untypical proposal, yet I think it is very neccessary to support contributors that go out of pocket or do free work if we don't want to deteiment the community efforts. This is exactly the case here as revelar have done great work, of which a lot was not funded, so i heavily support this proposal getting approved.
f6_assessments.q1: While for a proposal of this type it is difficult to make a typical implementation plan as required by the community standards, the proposer still have given their best to present something to justify the funding and explain the budget reasoning, in which they have succeeded. In addition to this, they have defined the deliverables that may result from their operations.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposers declared being very transparent about their finances and disclosing the progress of their work in regular updates. In general, the reasoning behind the proposal and the funds requested is pretty clear, so I consider this proposal quite auditable.

solution: This proposal aims to enable the required budget to reward Revelar core contributors, expand current capacity and services over 6 months.
experience: The Revelar team is a known contributor & has been received funding on several proposals in previous Catalyst Funds for our NFT gaming APIs. We proactively participate in building the Cardano Ecosystem and provide constant services to our Community to expand Cardano.
